components.name: Button
components.purpose: Triggers an action or event — the primary interactive element for user actions

variants.name: default
variants.when: Primary action. Main CTA. Use one per section for clear hierarchy.

variants.name: secondary
variants.when: Secondary actions with balanced visual weight. Pair with a default button.

variants.name: destructive
variants.when: Dangerous actions like deletion or removal. Always pair with confirmation.

variants.name: outline
variants.when: Secondary actions with less emphasis. Good for cancel buttons or alternative actions.

variants.name: ghost
variants.when: Tertiary actions with minimal emphasis. Toolbars, inline actions, subtle UI.

variants.name: link
variants.when: Navigation actions styled as text links. Use when action resembles a hyperlink.

accessibility.aria: Use semantic <button> element. Use aria-label for icon-only buttons.

antiPatterns: Don't use multiple default buttons in one section — breaks visual hierarchy
Don't use destructive variant without a confirmation step
Don't use Button for navigation — use Link instead
Don't use ghost variant for critical actions — too subtle
Don't omit labels on icon-only buttons (use aria-label)
examples: Form submissions: default variant
Delete actions: destructive variant with Alert Dialog confirmation
Cancel actions: outline variant
Toolbar actions: ghost variant
Secondary CTA: secondary variant

components.name: Alert
components.purpose: Displays a callout for important information that needs user attention

variants.name: default
variants.when: General information, tips, or neutral status messages.

variants.name: destructive
variants.when: Errors, warnings, or critical information that requires immediate attention.

accessibility.role: Implicit alert role through semantic structure
accessibility.aria: Use AlertTitle for heading hierarchy. Include icon + text (don't rely on color alone).

antiPatterns: Don't overuse alerts — reserve for genuinely important information
Don't rely solely on color to convey meaning — always include icon + text
Don't stack multiple alerts without clear information hierarchy
Don't use alerts for transient notifications — use Toast instead
examples: Form validation errors: destructive variant
Success confirmation: default variant with check icon
Important notices: default variant with info icon
System warnings: destructive variant with alert icon

components.name: Alert Dialog
components.purpose: Modal dialog for critical confirmations that require explicit user response before proceeding

variants.name: default
variants.when: Destructive or irreversible actions requiring confirmation (delete, remove, discard).

accessibility.keyboard: Escape to close. Tab cycles through actions. Enter activates focused button.
accessibility.focus: Focus trapped within dialog when open. Returns to trigger on close.
accessibility.aria: AlertDialogTitle and AlertDialogDescription announced to screen readers.

antiPatterns: Don't use for simple information — use Alert instead
Don't use for navigation or non-critical actions
Don't nest dialogs within dialogs
Don't remove the cancel option — always give users an escape route
Don't use for single-action confirmations — those should be inline
examples: Delete confirmation: 'Are you sure you want to delete this item?'
Discard unsaved changes: 'You have unsaved changes. Discard?'
Account actions: 'This will permanently delete your account.'

components.name: Input
components.purpose: Text input for forms and data entry with built-in styling and accessibility

variants.name: default
variants.when: Standard text entry. Most common form input.

variants.name: file
variants.when: File uploads. Set type='file'.

variants.name: disabled
variants.when: Non-interactive state. Use when input is contextually unavailable.

variants.name: invalid
variants.when: Validation error state. Pair with error message below.

accessibility.keyboard: Tab to focus, standard text editing keys
accessibility.aria: Use aria-invalid for error states. Always pair with a label (FieldLabel or <label>).
accessibility.required: Mark required fields with asterisk and required attribute

antiPatterns: Don't use placeholder as the only label — always include a visible label
Don't show invalid state without an accompanying error message
Don't use disabled inputs without explaining why they're disabled
Don't omit required field indicators
examples: Login form: email + password inputs with labels
Search: input with search icon in InputGroup
File upload: type='file' variant
Form validation: invalid state with FieldError

components.name: Card
components.purpose: Container for displaying grouped content with optional header, content, and footer sections

variants.name: default
variants.when: Standard content grouping. Most common card layout.

variants.name: small
variants.when: Compact appearance for dense layouts. Use size='sm'.

accessibility.keyboard: Interactive elements inside cards maintain focus visibility
accessibility.focus: Focus on interactive children, not the card itself
accessibility.aria: Use CardTitle for semantic heading hierarchy. CardDescription provides context.

antiPatterns: Don't nest cards within cards without clear visual hierarchy
Don't overload card content without proper section organization
Don't use CardAction for primary content — it's for supplementary actions
Don't ignore responsive spacing on small screens
examples: Login form card: header + content (form) + footer (submit button)
Dashboard metric: small card with title + value
Product card: image + header + content + footer (actions)
Settings section: card grouping related options

components.name: Dialog
components.purpose: Window overlaid on primary content for focused tasks — renders background inert

variants.name: default
variants.when: Forms, details, or focused interactions that don't fit inline.

variants.name: scrollable
variants.when: Long content that needs scrolling. Header stays fixed.

accessibility.keyboard: Escape closes dialog. Tab cycles through interactive elements.
accessibility.focus: Focus trapped within dialog. Initial focus on first interactive element. Returns to trigger on close.
accessibility.aria: DialogTitle and DialogDescription announced to screen readers. Dialog role auto-applied.

antiPatterns: Don't use for simple confirmations — use Alert Dialog instead
Don't nest dialogs within dialogs
Don't trap users without an escape route (always support Escape key)
Don't use for navigation
examples: Edit profile form: dialog with form fields + save/cancel
View details: dialog showing expanded content
Settings panel: dialog with tabbed content

components.name: Badge
components.purpose: Small visual indicator for status, category, or metadata labels

variants.name: default
variants.when: Standard labeling. Primary status indicator.

variants.name: secondary
variants.when: Supplementary information. Less emphasis than default.

variants.name: destructive
variants.when: Negative states, errors, or critical status.

variants.name: outline
variants.when: Subtle emphasis. Bordered badge for lighter UI.

accessibility.keyboard: Not interactive by default — informational only
accessibility.focus: Focusable only when used as a link (asChild with <a>)
accessibility.aria: Screen reader support via proper DOM structure. Don't rely on color alone.

antiPatterns: Don't use badges purely for decoration without semantic meaning
Don't overload a single view with too many badge variants
Don't rely on color alone for colorblind accessibility — include text
Don't use link variant without proper aria-label
examples: Status indicators: 'Active' (default), 'Expired' (destructive)
Category tags: outline variant
Notification count: default variant with number
Feature labels: secondary variant ('Beta', 'New')

components.name: Select
components.purpose: Dropdown list for picking from a set of options

variants.name: default
variants.when: Standard option selection. 5+ options or when space is limited.

variants.name: grouped
variants.when: Organized options with categories. Use SelectGroup + SelectLabel.

variants.name: scrollable
variants.when: Many options that need scrolling (10+ items).

accessibility.keyboard: Arrow keys to navigate options. Enter to select. Escape to close.
accessibility.focus: Focus management within dropdown. Returns to trigger on close.
accessibility.aria: aria-invalid on SelectTrigger for error states. Label association via FieldLabel.

antiPatterns: Don't use for fewer than 5 options — use Radio Group instead
Don't show invalid state without an error message
Don't overcrowd options without grouping or scrolling
Don't mix disabled and enabled items without clear visual distinction
examples: Theme selector: Light / Dark / System
Country picker: grouped by region with scroll
Form field: select with label and validation

components.name: Checkbox
components.purpose: Toggle control for binary checked/unchecked state — use for multi-select options

variants.name: default
variants.when: Standard binary toggle. Terms acceptance, feature toggles, multi-select lists.

variants.name: with-description
variants.when: Checkbox with additional help text below the label.

accessibility.keyboard: Space to toggle. Tab to navigate between checkboxes.
accessibility.focus: Visible focus ring on the checkbox element
accessibility.aria: aria-invalid for error states. Label association via FieldLabel.
accessibility.role: checkbox role applied automatically via Radix UI

antiPatterns: Don't use for mutually exclusive options — use Radio Group instead
Don't leave checkboxes unlabeled — always include descriptive text
Don't rely solely on color for checked/unchecked state
Don't place without proper spacing in dense layouts
examples: Terms acceptance: single checkbox with label
Feature toggles: grouped checkboxes with descriptions
Table row selection: checkbox in first column
Filter panel: multi-select checkboxes

components.name: Switch
components.purpose: Toggle control for on/off states — use for preferences and settings

variants.name: default
variants.when: Binary on/off toggle. Settings, preferences, feature flags.

variants.name: small
variants.when: Compact switch for dense UI. Use size='small'.

accessibility.keyboard: Space to toggle. Tab to navigate.
accessibility.aria: aria-invalid for error states. Label via FieldLabel.

antiPatterns: Don't use for multi-state selections — use Radio Group or Select instead
Don't omit labels or help text
Don't place without field context or label association
Don't use disabled state without explaining why
examples: Dark mode toggle: switch with 'Dark mode' label
Notification settings: switch per notification type
Feature flags: switch with description text
Privacy settings: grouped switches in a card

components.name: Tooltip
components.purpose: Popup that displays contextual information on hover or keyboard focus

variants.name: top
variants.when: Default position. Tooltip appears above the trigger.

variants.name: bottom
variants.when: Tooltip below trigger. Use when space above is limited.

variants.name: left
variants.when: Tooltip to the left. Use in right-aligned layouts.

variants.name: right
variants.when: Tooltip to the right. Use in left-aligned layouts.

accessibility.keyboard: Triggered by focus (Tab). Dismissed on Escape.
accessibility.focus: Appears on both hover and keyboard focus
accessibility.aria: Content announced to screen readers. For disabled buttons, wrap in <span> to enable tooltip.

antiPatterns: Don't use on elements that already have visible labels
Don't put critical information only in tooltips — not discoverable on mobile
Don't use long or complex content — keep it to a short phrase
Don't use for interactive content — tooltips disappear on mouse leave
examples: Icon button explanation: tooltip on icon-only button
Keyboard shortcut hint: 'Save (Ctrl+S)'
Disabled button reason: wrap in span, tooltip explains why disabled
Truncated text: show full text on hover

components.name: Radio Group
components.purpose: Set of mutually exclusive options where only one can be selected at a time

variants.name: default
variants.when: 2-5 mutually exclusive options. Use when all options should be visible.

variants.name: rich
variants.when: Card-style radio options with descriptions. Use for important choices needing more context.

accessibility.keyboard: Arrow keys to navigate between options. Space to select.
accessibility.focus: Focus moves between radio items with arrow keys
accessibility.aria: radiogroup role applied automatically. Each item has radio role.
accessibility.required: Use fieldset + legend for grouped radio options

antiPatterns: Don't use for non-exclusive selections — use Checkbox instead
Don't use for 6+ options — use Select instead
Don't omit labels on individual radio items
Don't use without a group label explaining the choice
examples: Plan selection: rich variant with plan details
Gender/preference: default variant with simple labels
Shipping method: rich variant with price + delivery time
Sort order: default variant (newest, oldest, popular)

spacing.componentGap: gap-2 (8px) for related elements, gap-4 (16px) for sections
spacing.padding: p-4 (16px) for cards, p-6 (24px) for dialogs

colors.primary: Used for primary actions and focus states
colors.destructive: Reserved for errors and dangerous actions only
colors.muted: For secondary text and disabled states
colors.accent: For hover states and subtle highlights
